info: Found in dense, wet stands of shrubs and saplings with minimal to no tree canopy. In addition to occurring in regenerating clearcuts, they are also regularly encountered in wetlands and along the margins of streams and lakes.

Typically found in open woodlands across North America. Special habitat features include weedy areas with an abundance of composite flowers (especially thistles and dandelions) which provide food (seeds) and nest material.
Occurs in regenerating patch and clearcuts, but also occur in mature deciduous forests with dense saplings or pole-sized trees. Can be seen probing for insects along tree trunks and branches.

Prefers openings with dense cover of herbaceous vegetation and patchy shrub/sapling cover. Although they are shrubland specialists, they will use small patches, and they will tolerate the presence of some mature trees. One of the species of highest conservation concern in Massachusetts.

Large and secretive birds that inhabit open areas with dense clusters of shrubs. This species prefers dry habitats with deep litter cover, where they forage for insects and mast. Brown thrashers have one of the most extensive repertoires of any North American songbird.

Tolerant of moderate levels of canopy cover, and are associated with moderate to high densities of saplings and shrubs. An understory with moss and coarse woody debris may provide important habitat for this species. One of the highest priority birds in terms of conservation status in Massachusetts.

This fruit-eating species is attracted to open areas with few tall trees and numerous berry-producing shrubs, especially native shrubs. Fruit availability is crucial to habitat selection, so cedar waxwings can be found in berry bushes, evergreens, and along the banks of rivers and ponds.

Inhabits areas with dense shrub and sapling cover. They occur in clearcuts, but also nest in shelterwood cuts, although at lower densities. They make frequent forays into adjacent mature forest for forage and collect nesting material, particularly birch bark.
Associated with dense herbaceous vegetation. In addition to silvicultural openings, they occur in wetlands, riparian areas and fallow field on farms.

A northerly species commonly found in dry areas with moderate to dense cover of shrubs and herbaceous vegetation. Juncos may use areas occupied by taller trees, provided the canopy is somewhat open. Slash and coarse woody debris may be important habitat features for this species.
This large sparrow can be found along the shrubby edges of forests, thickets, and old fields. Eastern towhees prefer dry, open habitats with relatively few trees and dense to patchy shrub cover.
Inhabits dry, grassy areas with low to moderate shrub cover. Some small trees may be tolerated. They are one of the most area-sensitive species that occur in silvicultural openings in Massachusetts.

Breeds in sites with patchy shrub cover and dense herbaceous vegetation. Golden-winged warblers are one of the highest priority species in Massachusetts with respect to its conservation status and are very sparsely distributed.

A relative of thrashers and mockingbirds, gray catbirds have the ability to mimic the sounds of other species. They use habitats with low or open canopies, and dense patches of shrubs and saplings, including residential yards.
This brightly colored bird occupies open areas with moderate to dense shrub cover and dense herbaceous vegetation. Indigo buntings will use forest edges and areas with some tall trees for song posts.

This northerly distributed species uses open to moderately closed habitats with low, dense shrubby vegetation. Mourning warblers occur in regenerating clearcuts, but also shelterwoods, although at lower densities.

This northerly species is almost never found in unbroken forests, but they may inhabit areas with small or scattered large trees. They breed in moderately open areas with dense shrub cover and a dense herbaceous layer.
Occurs in openings with little herbaceous groundcover, is highly area-sensitive, and is relatively intolerant of residual trees. One of the highest priority species in Massachusetts.

This widespread species prefers habitats with tall, dense shrub or sapling cover and dense herbaceous vegetation, preferably “mesic” (moister) sites. Song sparrows also occur in wetlands, residential areas and in fallow areas on farms.

Areas with dense, low shrub cover provide ideal habitat for this southerly species. White-eyed vireos are relatively intolerant of residual canopy coverage, are also one of the more area-sensitive species in Massachusetts forest openings.

This northerly species is typical of coniferous habitats with dense shrub cover and significant herbaceous vegetation, although they will also use deciduous habitats. In addition to silvicultural openings, this species also may occur along the edges of meadows, bogs, and ponds, as well as areas regenerating after fires.

This elusive bird is a voracious predator of caterpillars, cicadas, and other large insects. Yellow-billed cuckoos almost exclusively found in deciduous habitats, often near water. Areas with dense shrubs and saplings are preferred, such as abandoned agricultural land, overgrown orchards, and the edges of streams and marshes.
Associated with deciduous or mixed forest, particularly shaded ravines, wooded bottomlands and riparian areas.
A species of wood warbler, typically occupies deciduous forest with a dense midstory and saplings. Flashes red tail feathers to flush insects which it captures in flight.
A canopy-dweller associated with mature mixed or coniferous forests including spruce or hemlock. Abundant in regenerating clearcuts during the post-fledging period.
Uses deciduous or mixed forest with dense understories. A shrub nester typically uses hobblebush in its northern range, mountain laurel in the south.
Occupies mixed forests canopies, particularly associated with spruce and hemlock. Lab experiments show innate preference for red over white spruce.
Prefers open moist deciduous forests. Quiet sibilant song often includes snippets of songs of other species. Flashes tail spots to flush insect prey like American redstart.
Prefers mixed or coniferous forest, especially hemlock or spruce. One of the earliest returning migrants to northern forests. Unlike red-eyed vireo, males also incubate eggs.
Inhabits mature coniferous, mixed or deciduous forest where it probes bark crevices for invertebrate prey. Nests in exfoliating bark, so values standing dead trees and snags.

Associated with upper canopies of mature deciduous forests with large white oaks, sugar maples and hickories on bottomlands in the south, but mid to upper slopes and ridgelines in the northern portion of their range.
Typically occupies mid-to upper canopy in upland mature deciduous forests. Pursues insects in acrobatic flights from an exposed perch. Once of the last arrivals to northern forests.
Nests in dense coniferous or mixed upland forests. Forages and nests on the ground, sometimes by rapidly stamping their feet, perhaps to flush invertebrates? Known to eat red-backed salamanders.
Prefers deciduous or mixed moist forest with dense understory, often associated with gaps. Also flashes white spots in tail feathers to flush insect prey that it captures in flight.
A bird of the Southeast, forages on the floor of deciduous woods with damp thickets in bottomlands or near water courses, ravines and swamps in uplands. Nests on or near the ground.
Occupies open forests, often nests in clusters of territories, may exclude American redstarts from preferred habitat.

A dweller of deciduous, mixed or coniferous forests with sparse woody understory but well-developed herbaceous layer. Nests and forages on the forest floor, males sing from the mid-canopy, but also make elaborate flight displays above the canopy, typically near dusk.
Occupies coniferous forests, excavates nest cavities in trees with rotted cores. Spreads resin from pines or spruces around nest hole to deter predators.

A canopy dweller typical of upland or bottomland deciduous forest with well-developed sapling layer. One of the more prolific songsters, one observer counted over 22,000 songs in a single day. Consumes spongy and brown-tailed moths.
Inhabits mature or second growth woods with a well-developed sapling layer.
Occurs most frequently in mature deciduous and mixed forest where it nests and forages in the canopy.
Nests in moist mixed or deciduous forest with well-developed shrub layer, typically near streams and seeps. Forages and nests on or near the ground.
Occupies moist deciduous or mixed forest with well developed midstory. Forages principally on the ground, nests in taller shrubs or saplings.
Uses moist forest, wooded ravines and hillsides often near running water and typically with dense understory tangles.
Inhabits deciduous or mixed forests, excavates nesting cavities in trees with decayed centers. Drills rows of holes in bark and consumes sap and insects drawn to it.

A canopy dweller of coniferous or mixed forests. Eastern birds formerly known as "Myrtle warblers" because of their unusual habit of eating wax myrtle (aka "bayberry") fruits, which may enable them to winter further north than most other warbler species.
